'''Love''' is an [[emotion]] of strong [[affection]] and personal [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]].<ref name="oxford">''Oxford Illustrated American Dictionary'' (1998) + ''Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary'' (2000)</ref> In philosophical context, love is a [[virtue]] representing all of human [[kindness]], [[compassion]], and affection. Love is central to many [[religion]]s, as in the Christian phrase, "[[God is love]]" or [[Agape]] in the [[Canonical gospels]].<ref>[[Deus Caritas Est]], Roman Catholic encyclical by Pope Benedict XVI</ref> Love may also be described as actions towards others (or oneself) based on compassion.<ref name="Fromm, Eric 1956">Fromm, Eric; "The Art of Loving", Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN 978-0060958282</ref> Or as actions towards others based on affection.<ref name="Fromm, Eric 1956"/>
 
'''Love''' is an [[emotion]] of strong [[affection]] and personal [[attachment (psychology)|attachment]].<ref name="oxford">''Oxford Illustrated American Dictionary'' (1998) + ''Merriam-Webster Collegiate Dictionary'' (2000)</ref> In philosophical context, love is a [[virtue]] representing all of human [[kindness]], [[compassion]], and affection. Love is central to many [[religion]]s, as in the Christian phrase, "[[God is love]]" or [[Agape]] in the [[Canonical gospels]].<ref>[[Deus Caritas Est]], Roman Catholic encyclical by Pope Benedict XVI</ref> Love may also be described as actions towards others (or oneself) based on compassion.<ref name="Fromm, Eric 1956">Fromm, Eric; "The Art of Loving", Harper Perennial (1956), Original English Version, ISBN 978-0060958282</ref> Or as actions towards others based on affection.<ref name="Fromm, Eric 1956"/>
